metadata.title: Suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 infection in cell culture by interfering

abstract.text: The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic that originated from Wuhan, China, in December 2019 has impacted public 48 health, society and economy and the daily lives of billions of people in an unprecedented manner. 49
There are currently no specific registered antiviral drugs to treat or prevent SARS-CoV-2 infections. 50
Therefore, drug repurposing would be the fastest route to provide at least a temporary solution while 51
better, more specific drugs are being developed. Here we demonstrate that the antiparasitic drug 52

suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 replication, protecting Vero E6 cells with an EC50 of ~20 µM, which is well 53 below the maximum attainable level in human serum. Suramin also decreased the viral load by 2-3 54 logs when Vero E6 cells or cells of a human lung epithelial cell line (Calu-3) were treated. Time of 55 addition and plaque reduction assays showed that suramin acts on early steps of the replication cycle, 56
possibly preventing entry of the virus. In a primary human airway epithelial cell culture model, suramin 57 also inhibited the progression of infection.

body_text.text: Cytopathic effect (CPE) reduction assay 167 CPE reduction assays were performed as described (22). Briefly, Vero E6 cells were seeded in 96-well 168 cell culture plates at a density of 10 4 cells per well. Cells were incubated with 1.7-fold serial dilutions 169 of suramin starting from a concentration of 120 µM. Subsequently, cells were either mock-infected 170

body_text.text: (analysis of cytotoxicity of the compound) or were infected with 300 PFU of virus per well (MOI of 171 0.015) in a total volume of 150 µl of medium. Cell viability was assessed three days post-infection by 172

The 50% 174 effective concentration (EC50), required to inhibit virus-induced cell death by 50%, and the 50% 175 cytotoxic concentration (CC50), that reduces the viability of uninfected cells to 50% of that of untreated 176 control cells, were determined using non-linear regression with GraphPad Prism v8.0. 177 178 Viral load reduction assays 179

body_text.text: Cells were seeded in 96-well cell culture plates at a density of 10 4 (Vero E6) or 6 x 10 4 (Calu-3) cells per 180 well in 100 µl culture medium. As control to determine the amount of residual virus after removal of 181 the inoculum and washing, cells in some wells were killed with 70% Ethanol (followed by washing with 182 PBS). Vero E6 and Calu-3 cells were incubated with 2-fold serial dilutions of a starting concentration 183

body_text.text: Analysis of viral progeny in supernatant from Calu-3 cells was performed by plaque assay on Vero E6 187 cells (17). Potential cytotoxicity of the compound was tested in parallel on uninfected cells using the 188 MTS assay (Promega) as described for the CPE reduction assay. 189 190

body_text.text: A day before infection Vero E6 cells were seeded in 6-well cell culture plates at a density of 3.5 x 10 5 192 cells per well in 2 ml medium. 10 -2 to 10 -5 -fold serial dilutions of a SARS-COV-2 stock were prepared in 193 medium containing 100, 50, 25, 12.5, 6.25 or 0 µM suramin. These were used as inoculum to infect 194 the Vero E6 cells in 6-well clusters. After 1 h at 37 o C, the inoculum was removed and cells were 195 incubated in Avicel-containing overlay medium without suramin for 3 days, after which they were 196 fixed with 3.7% formaldehyde, stained with crystal violet and plaques were counted (17). 197 198 Time of addition assay 199

body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 replication in Vero E6 cells 222
To determine if suramin could protect cells from SARS-CoV-2 infection and to evaluate its toxicity, 223

Vero E6 cells were infected with SARS-CoV-2 and treated with serial dilutions of suramin in a CPE 224 reduction assay. Suramin protected infected cells from SARS-CoV-2-induced cell death in a dose-225 dependent manner, with an EC50 of 20 ± 2,7 µM (Fig. 1A) . In parallel, non-infected cells were treated 226

with the same concentrations of suramin in order to assess the compound's toxicity. No toxicity was 227 observed over the range of concentrations that was used in these antiviral assays. Only at 5 mM cell 228 viability dropped to 67%, resulting in a CC50 > 5 mM (15). Therefore, suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 with 229 a selectivity index (SI) higher than 250. 230
To more directly measure the inhibition of viral replication by suramin, viral load reduction assays 231

were performed. Vero E6 cells were infected with SARS-CoV-2 at an MOI of 1 and they were treated 232 with increasing concentrations of suramin. At 16 h.p.i., supernatant was harvested to determine the 233 viral load by quantifying the levels of extracellular viral RNA by RT-qPCR ( Fig 1B) .

To assess the antiviral effect of suramin in a more relevant model, human lung epithelial cells (Calu-3)  255 were infected with 2 x 10 4 PFU of SARS-CoV-2 in the presence of 0-200 µM suramin for 1h. After 256 removal of the inoculum and washing of the cells, incubation was continued in medium with suramin 257 (0-200 µM) for 20 hours. At 21 h.p.i., RNA was isolated from cells and supernatant and the viral titer 258

body_text.text: Cytotoxicity assays performed in parallel in non-infected Calu-3 cells showed that suramin was slightly 268 more toxic to these cells than to Vero E6 cells, although cell viability remained above 80% even at the 269 highest dose tested (Fig. 2D ). Together these results suggest that suramin is a potent SARS-CoV-2 270

body_text.text: To determine which step of viral replication is affected by suramin, we performed a time-of-addition 294 assay. Cells were infected with SARS-CoV-2 (MOI 1) and treated with 100 µM of suramin over different 295 time intervals, as schematically depicted in Figure 3A . Treatment was initiated 1 hour before infection 296 or at 0, 1, 2, 4, 6 or 8 h.p.i., and suramin remained present until 10 h.p.i., when supernatants were 297 harvested to determine viral load by RT-qPCR targeting the RdRp coding region. In one sample suramin 298 was only present for 60 min during the time of infection. After 1 hour, virus inoculum was removed 299
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: and cells were washed three times with PBS, followed by incubation in medium with or without 300

body_text.text: suramin. At 10 h.p.i., supernatant was collected to evaluate the levels of viral RNA (Fig. 3B ). When 301 suramin treatment was initiated 1 hour before (-1h) or at the time of infection (0h) a 2-log reduction 302 in viral RNA levels was observed. Treatments that started later than 1 hour post infection did not 303 inhibit viral replication, as viral RNA levels similar to the non-treated control were observed. 304
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: Treatment only during the infection (0-1h) resulted in the same 2-log reduction in viral RNA load as 305 the 0-10h treatment, indicating that suramin inhibits an early step of the replication cycle, likely viral 306 entry. 307

body_text.text: To confirm suramin's inhibitory effect on entry, we performed a plaque reduction assay, by infecting 308

body_text.text: Vero E6 cells with serial dilutions of SARS-CoV-2 in the presence of increasing concentrations of 309 suramin, which was only present during the one hour of infection. After infection, cells were washed 310 3 times with PBS and were incubated with overlay medium without suramin. After 3 days, cells were 311 fixed, stained and plaques were counted. Suramin caused a dose-dependent reduction in the number 312 of plaques and even at the lowest suramin concentration (12.5 µM) titers were already reduced by 313 almost one log (Fig. 3C) . These results suggest that suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 entry. in untreated cells, while at 48h a more than 1 log increase in viral RNA copies was observed. This is 339
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: indicative of (very modest) viral replication in PBS-treated cells. The cultures that were treated with 340 suramin displayed no increase in viral load in the supernatant, but rather even a slight decrease in 341 copy numbers, suggesting viral replication did not progress in treated cells. At 48 h.p.i. the supernatant 342 of suramin-treated cells showed 2-log lower SARS-CoV-2 released genome copy numbers than PBS-343 treated control cells (Fig. 4A) . The levels of intracellular viral RNA displayed the same trend, with a 344 decrease in viral RNA in suramin-treated samples compared to an increase in viral RNA in PBS-treated 345 samples (Fig. 4B) . A 1-log difference, from 10 6 to 10 5 copies per transwell was observed at 48 h.p.i. 346

body_text.text: between suramin-and PBS-treated cells (Fig. 4B ). The levels of the housekeeping gene, PGK1 remained 347 stable in all samples, suggesting the reduction in viral RNA copies was not due to cell death. Moreover, 348 cell viability measured by MTS assay (Fig. 4C) not provide much benefit to COVID-19 patients and could actually be dangerous due to possible side-380 effects. This leaves us currently empty-handed and in search for other approved drugs that might be 381

body_text.text: repurposed. As an already approved antiparasitic drug, suramin would be one of the candidates for 382 fast development of a treatment for COVID-19. Antiviral activity of suramin against RNA viruses was 383

body_text.text: reported earlier by us and several other groups (15, 29-31) and the compound was and is also being 384 evaluated in several clinical trials for other diseases, providing some evidence for its safety for 385 therapeutic use. However, suramin can also cause several side-effects, which caused previous HIV 386 trials with seriously ill patients to halt (32) and therefore caution is advised and it is crucial to conduct 387 well controlled randomized trials, before any conclusions on possible benefits for COVID-19 patients 388

body_text.text: In this study we assessed the antiviral activity of suramin against the newly emerged SARS-CoV-2. 391
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: Suramin offered full protection against SARS-CoV-2-induced cell death in Vero E6 cells and inhibited 392 the virus with an EC 50 of 20 µM and a SI of >250 (Fig. 1) . Suramin treatment of infected Vero E6 cells 393 led to a reduction in extracellular viral RNA levels of up to 3 log. The highest concentration of 394
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: compound that was used proved harmless to the cells and also previously cytotoxicity was only 395 observed above 5 mM (15). Suramin also displayed antiviral efficacy in a human lung epithelial cell 396 line and we observed a >2 log reduction in infectious virus progeny in suramin-treated cells. 397 Suramin was previously described to have the potential to inhibit several stages of virus replication by 398 acting on different targets (15, 33) . To assess which step in the SARS-CoV-2 replication cycle is affected 399 by suramin treatment, we performed a time-of-addition assay. We observed that pre-treatment with 400 suramin as well as addition during the first hour of infection resulted in a marked decrease of viral 401 RNA in the supernatant, while treatments initiated after the first hour of infection showed no 402 significant effect on virus replication, suggesting that suramin inhibits binding or entry. In addition, 403 SARS-CoV-2 infectivity was decreased in plaque assays, when suramin was present only in the 404 inoculum during infection, concordant with an effect on the early stages of infection (Fig. 3) . This is in 405 agreement with other studies that also reported on the inhibition of virus binding or entry by suramin 406 (15, 30, 34) . Our data suggest that the antiviral effect of suramin is primarily due to inhibition of 407 binding and/or fusion. 408
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: Finally we evaluated the effect of suramin in a more relevant model of differentiated primary human 409 airway epithelial (HAE) cells cultured and infected at the physiologically relevant air-liquid interface. 410
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: We infected these cells with a relatively low dose of virus (estimated MOI of 0. Administration of 100 µM of suramin on the apical side of the HAE cells did not appear to cause 425 cytotoxic effects in our study (Fig. 4) containing samples needed to be diluted by a 100-fold to exclude interference with the plaque assay, 434 the limit of detection would be 100 pfu/ml. Even with this limit of detection, the supernatant collected 435 from suramin-treated HAE cells contains at least 100 times less virus than that from PBS-treated cells. 436
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: Much higher titers were obtained with HAE cultures from mixed donors than from single donors, but 437 the inhibitory effect of suramin was also observed with single donor cultures. Overall, despite the 438 modest level of infection in control cells, our results suggest that also in the HAE infection model, 439
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: suramin has an inhibitory effect on progression of the SARS-CoV-2 infection. 440
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: Our study demonstrates that suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 replication in various cell culture models 441 and at clinically achievable concentrations (after IV administration serum levels of >10x the EC50 could 442 be achieved). Due to its mode of action (inhibition of entry) treatment of patients with suramin might 443 require administration at an early stage, although it might also prevent spread of the virus in the lungs 444 of already symptomatic patients or could prevent spread from respiratory tract to other organs. It 445 might possibly even be used to prevent virus spreading in the nasopharynx, which appears to be the 446 first site of infection (39-41). Standard treatment with suramin is done by intravenous administration, 447 which would also be an option for seriously ill COVID-19 patients that are in intensive care, but is not 448 ideal for other patients. As a negatively charged compound, suramin binds to various proteins and is 449 poorly taken up by diffusion across the cell membrane, although it can be taken up by endocytosis 450
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: (33). This poor uptake of suramin into cells might not necessarily be a problem for the efficacy against 451 SARS-CoV-2, as it is expected to block the virus systemically and in the extracellular environment. 452
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: Hypothetically, suramin administration into the respiratory tract in an aerosolized form could be even 453 considered, although this requires new safety studies. 454
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: In conclusion, our preclinical study shows that suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 replication in cell culture, 455
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: likely by preventing entry. Suramin also appears to prevent progression of SARS-CoV-2 infection in a 456 human airway epithelial cell culture model. This is only the first step towards evaluating whether 457 suramin treatment could provide any benefit to COVID-19 patients. Further studies should carefully 458 evaluate different formulations, routes of administration, pharmacokinetics, and possible adverse 459 effects in cell culture and ex vivo models. Ultimately, the clinical benefits of suramin for the treatment 460
body_text.section: Figure 2. Suramin decreases levels of intra-and extracellular viral RNA and infectious progeny in 282 infected Calu-3 cells. Calu-3 cells were infected with SARS-CoV

body_text.text: of COVID-19 patients should be evaluated in carefully performed and properly controlled clinical trials. 461 462 463

FIGREF2.text: Suramin inhibits the early steps of SARS-CoV-2 replication. (A) Schematic representation of319 the time-of-addition experiment and the different treatment intervals. (B) At 10 h.p.i. supernatant was 320 harvested and extracellular viral RNA levels were determined by RT-qPCR. (C) Vero E6 cells were 321 infected with SARS-CoV-2 in the presence of various concentrations of suramin. Suramin was only 322 present during the one hour of infection and after 1 hour, cells were incubated in overlay medium 323 without suramin. After three days, cells were fixed, stained and plaques were counted. (n=3). 324 325 Suramin inhibits SARS-CoV-2 replication in a primary human epithelial airway cell infection model 326 Primary human airway epithelial cell cultures (HAE) mimic the morphological and physiological 327 features of the human conducting airway, arguably being the most relevant ex vivo model for human 328 coronavirus research (23-25). For that reason, we decided to also evaluate the antiviral effect of 329 suramin in this model. HAE were differentiated by culture at the air-liquid interface to achieve 330 mucociliary differentiation, and were infected for one hour with 30,000 PFU of SARS-CoV-2 (estimated 331 MOI of 0.1 based on the number of cells present on an insert), followed by washing with PBS. At 12 332 and 24 h.p.i., the cultures were treated on the apical side with either 50 µl of 100 µM suramin or 50 333 µl PBS. The HAE apical side was washed with PBS for 10 minutes at 37°C, and this supernatant was 334 harvested at 12, 24 and 48 h.p.i. to analyze the viral load by RT-qPCR. RNA was also isolated from cells 335 to quantify the levels of intracellular viral RNA and the housekeeping gene PGK1. RT-qPCR analysis of 336 extracellular viral RNA levels showed that after infection approximately 10 7 copies/ml of viral RNA 337 remained at 1 h.p.i.. The viral load in the supernatant did not increase significantly at 12 and 24 h.p.i. 338

TABREF4.text: the fusion activity of the spike protein, also inhibited infection in lung cells (37). To address 419 the variation of these proteins and the diversity of primary human airway cells within patients, we 420 made use of HAE cultures that were obtained from different donors. Notably, we could observe 421 differences in the susceptibility of cultures from different donors, in which HAE cultures from mixed 422 donors showed higher titers. HAE cultures might have varying susceptibility to infection, possibly 423 caused by a difference in cell differentiation and composition (38). 424

TABREF5.text: . In our HAE model for progression of SARS-CoV-2 infection, we 426 infected cells at a low MOI and observed a modest (~200-fold) increase in viral load by 48 h.p.i. in PBS-427 treated cultures. Although the increase in viral load was rather modest in control cells, we found no 428 evidence for progression of the infection in suramin-treated cultures, as indicated by SARS-CoV-2 RNA 429 levels that remained equal to that at 1 h.p.i. or even decreased over time. Moreover, the infectious 430 progeny titer increased over time in PBS-treated HAE cultures and reached over 10 4 PFU/ml by 48 431 h.p.i, while in suramin-treated HAE cells, infectious progeny showed a modest increase at 24 h.p.i. (10 432 fold lower than PBS-treated cells) and dropped to undetectable levels at 48 h.p.i. Since suramin-433
